Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2013 10:06PM summergal wrote: So glad I found this thread.   I finally made the decision last night to do lumpectomy at a cancer center (as opposed to a general surgeon), and I thought "Good, well, there, I finally made a decision," and then woke up this morning....panicked thinking "what if the cancer comes back?  Won't I wish I'd done the MX in the first place?"  I don't want to have regrets.  I've been told by the BC surgeon that I'm a candidate for LX (small tumors, Stage 1, ER+/PR+/Her2-), but I have just felt sick to my stomach again all day because of having to make this decision between two not-so-great options.  Wish I could just put this burden down for a while.
Posts.Title: How did you decide on lumpectomy or mastectomy/ livingwithit IrishDancingMom

Posts.Content: summergal wrote: Morning!  I'm wondering how tumor size is determined after core biopsies.  I had several core biopsies with malignancies and I'm being told that the one tumor (ILC) on LB is 2mm and one (IMC) on RB is 6mm.  This information was accompanied with "these sizes are based on the core samples, so the tumors could be bigger when we get in there for surgery."  How do I used this information to make a surgical decision?  These seem like very small tumors, but I know that ILC can be sneaky, in particular, and am trying to use all the information I can to make an informed decision about lumpectomy vs. mastectomy.  Thank you!  Sending out positive vibes to everyone.   Synchronous Bilateral Breast Cancer, Gated Breathing Radiation Therapy, Oncotypes 7 and 14 Dx 6/21/2013, ILC, <1cm, Stage IA, Grade 2, 0/1 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Dx 7/9/2013, IDC, 1cm, Stage IA, Grade 2, 0/2 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 9/11/2013 Lumpectomy: Left, Right; Lymph node removal: Left, Right, Sentinel Radiation Therapy 11/12/2013 Whole-breast: Breast, Chest wall Hormonal Therapy 2/9/2014 Tamoxifen pills (Nolvadex, Apo-Tamox, Tamofen, Tamone) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2013 03:24PM summergal wrote: Hello - I'm so sorry for your diagnosis, but glad that you have posted here.  I think you will find this a very caring and supportive community, who are always willing to listen and help.  I'm going to try and help you with some of the lingo you're about to discover as a newly diagnosed breast cancer patient.  I was diagnosed (DX is the acronym used for diagnosis) on June 21 with Invasive Lobular Carcinoma (ILC) in my left breast.  It was found through a mammogram, I have no family history at all.  Shortly after that DX, my general surgeon ordered an MRI - that was a bit jarring, as it's very loud and bang-y in there, but thankfully I didn't go in head first!  If you have to have an MRI for further screening, be sure and ask the tech to give you headphones so they can play music for you during the MRI.  You will have to stay completely still, but you can do it!  After I had my MRI, I had an ultrasound biopsy (US) and the radiologist found additional cancer, Invasive Ductal Carcinoma (IDC), in my right breast.  So I have Synchronous Bilateral Breast Cancer.  Some good things for you to ask your doctor - is my cancer "estrogen and progesterone receptor positive? (ER+/PR+)"  Is my cancer "Her2/Neu negative?"  Both of these characteristics are considered good from a prognostic perspective.  If your cancer is ER+/PR+, this means your cancer cells are feeding off the estrogen in your body, so after your surgery, the Medical Oncologist (MO) might recommend hormone therapy in order to reduce your estrogen levels.  One of the drugs that does this is Tamoxifen.  You will hear a lot of people talk about this drug.  Her2 negative means generally means that your cancer is not very aggressive, or fast-growing.  Another thing to ask is "what is the size of my tumor?"  The doctor may not be able to give you a specific answer, as the biopsy only generally determines the size, but it's helpful to know this as it may give you an idea of how long you can wait to have surgery (generally, the larger the tumor, the quicker the surgery).  Another thing to know, and this can be very difficult to swallow, is that you will most likely have surgery.  That is the go-to treatment for most breast cancers.  Some women have very large tumors and they have to be shrunk first with radiation, chemo or a combo, but most women will be told they have to have surgery - either mastectomy (MX) or lumpectomy (LX), which is sometimes called "partial mastectomy" by the medical community.  This news was very shocking to me as I simply didn't feel sick!  I couldn't believe that "just yesterday" (i.e., before breast cancer, or BBC!) I was fine and after diagnosis, the main thing everyone talked about was surgery.  The important thing to remember is this - if your tumors are small (under 1 cm), your hormone receptors are positive and your Her2 is negative, you have some time to take this all in before you immediately rush to surgery and DON'T let any doctor push you into anything.  You have the right to a second opinion and I highly recommend it.  Even if you love your general surgeon, as I did.  I still was advised to see a Breast Cancer Specialist or Surgical Oncologist (BS or SO).  I'm glad I did.  I realized I had more than one option.  My BS does hundreds of breast cancer surgeries (not just breast surgeries) a year; my general surgeon only did tens of them.  I eventually chose to have bilateral lumpectomies with sentinel node biopsies (SNB) - this is where the surgeon injects a small bit of blue dye or a radioactive isotope into your breast tissue, then watches it travel to the first of your lymph nodes under your arm.  When the dye shows which one is the biggest, first or "sentinel" lymph node, the surgeon will cut into your skin and take that node out and have it tested to see if the cancer has spread to your lymph nodes.  If it has, you will most likely need chemotherapy. If you choose LX, you will have radiation therapy (RT or RADS) several weeks afterwards.  But...you are nowhere near that now!!  You have just been diagnosed and it is the scariest time.  A BC sister told me the worst time is between diagnosis and when you finally decide on which surgical treatment to have.  That was true for me. It is so scary and unbelievable and it makes you have to face firsthand things you probably have never thought about.  But you are going to be okay.  Reach out to your family and friends.  Post on this board.  DO NOT spend a lot of time on the internet looking for information - this site is a dot-org and it is a rich and wonderful source of information.  Ask questions.  And again, it is okay to seek a second opinion.  If you're wondering how to do this, look online for a cancer center near you.  Give them a call.  You may even be able to register for your appt online.  Above all, keep breathing.  It is going to be hard for you to sleep for the next few weeks or months.  But know this - we are here for you.  You're one of us now.  It's not the club anyone wants to join, but if you have to have breast cancer, we are here and we know what you're going through.  ((((HUGS))))
Posts.Title: In Total Shock!!!!!!! carissabforlife Kiko

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2013 09:45AM summergal wrote: Kiko  - I'm so sorry for your diagnosis, and also that your concerns were dismissed over the past three years!  Isn't it ironic? As a physician, you were a patient, too, and your doctor didn't take you seriously.   I'm so glad though that you sought treatment and will be starting chemo (not the best thing, but it should help shrink the tumor, as you said).  I hope the biopsy comes back clear.  I have synchronous bilateral BC - not very common, and recently had lumpectomies on each breast.  Just hold onto those dear little babies of yours - it is scary, but I think being distracted by their needs and your work will help.  Everyone tells you to keep busy so that you don't spend too much time in your own head during these early days of your diagnosis.  I think that's good advice.  It does get better.  You will not always feel as you do today!  ((HUGS))
Posts.Title: In Total Shock!!!!!!! carissabforlife Kiko

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2013 10:33AM summergal wrote: Kiko - Even though you had your biopsies yesterday I still want to wish you Happy Birthday!  Cancer changes many things, but it cannot change the fact that today, right now, you are alive...and I've found that celebrations become even more meaningful now.  I was just thinking this morning, maybe god gives us a quest, as in the medieval times, or maybe we are given a challenge to draw nearer to our own source of divinity.  What amazes me is how resilient we are as humans.  We here on this forum have received what we perhaps never saw coming - a diagnosis that forces us to look at how we live and that we live.  And even in our pain (as you will find out when you read some of the other forums about surgery, etc.), humans perservere, amazingly, inspirationally.  We do what we have to to live.  Because it's what we were born to do, to live.  We are mighty.  You are, too.  ((HUGS))
Posts.Title: In Total Shock!!!!!!! carissabforlife Kiko

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2013 02:41AM summergal wrote: I feel so bad for all of us who can't sleep - wish it weren't so - at a time when our bodies really need the rest and rebuilding, we're denied that opportunity by all the stress and worry we're under.  Fiddle - I feel as you do - I worry every time I read what someone else has chosen and wonder if I've made the right decision for my surgery.  I think, "am I crazy to think I can get away with 'just' lumpectomies?  I have cancer in both breasts...shouldn't I be desperate to get it all out, even the healthy tissue?"  I'm just holding onto what my surgeon said - that I'm still a candidate for preservation.  But I worry that it won't be enough, and that I'll regret not having the MX.  I also feel like I'm in this strange place of limbo regarding support - when I was first diagnosed, I told my family and close friends, then branched out to other friends, and then to a wider circle of associates, colleagues, etc.  There was immediate kindness and support...but I just noticed today that I feel "removed" from everyone's lives.  I'm not saying I want or need them to be calling me 24-7.  It's funny how everyone offers "whatever you need" when you're first diagnosed and you have no idea, really, what's going on, or what you need...  Hope everyone can have a restful night tonight. Peaceful thoughts...

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2013 02:52PM summergal wrote: hobbesla4 - how long ago did you have your lumpectomy?  I'm asking because mine were 3 weeks ago today and earlier this week I started having a lot of soreness on my right breast (the tumor there was bigger than the one they took out of my left breast, and I know they had to cut all the way back to the chest wall on the right breast), and you describe the pain feeling like it comes from inside.  That's what mine feels like.  I had "zingers" for the first time on Monday but they went away after one day and then the constant soreness remained.  I thought it must just be the feeling of the nerves regenerating, but I'm beginning to worry about the soreness.  I have little to no pain in the left breast.  I'm sorry you have to have the re-excision, but hopefully that might resolve the seroma, or it will resolve before then.
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2013 02:46PM summergal wrote: tuffenough - I think it's every bit within your patient rights to reschedule your surgery so you don't miss helping with your daughter's wedding.  When I was first diagnosed, I was amazed at how quickly I became "my doctor's patient" - i.e., my doctor's office TOLD when to come in for appts, they didn't ask if they were convenient for my schedule.  And when I was first diagnosed, I was, of course, in abject terror, so I was complying with absolutely everything the doctor said to do.  Not sure what your diagnosis is, how aggressive your cancer is, etc. (you can add that information by updating your profile if you wish), but it might be worth a phone call on Tuesday morning to your doctor's office to see if you can get a little leeway so your surgery doesn't interfere with the wedding.  That said, and I'm going on hearsay here, I've heard that many are back to normal activities within a few days of lumpectomies, and you might have more peace of mind AFTER the surgery to be able to really enjoy the wedding. ((hugs))!
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2013 03:10AM summergal wrote: tuffenough - have you been told the size of your tumor?  Do you know the characteristics of your cancer (i.e., is it estrogen positive, progesterone positive, Her2 negative...or is it triple negative?)?  Knowing some of these can help you determine if you absolutely need to act this quickly or not.  I would strongly suggest you seek a second opinion.  The tricky thing is, in the initial stages of the breast cancer diagnosis, being told to seek a second opinion is like being told to go climb Mt. Everest - how?  Depending on where you live, are there cancer centers nearby or within a reasonable traveling distance?  Can you give another hospital/center a call tomorrow morning and say you would like to schedule a second opinion?  Sometimes you can even register online for a second opinion appointment (which I did, and was called by an intake facilitator within hours).  Any really good surgeon would fully support you in seeking a second opinion.  I can understand how you are feeling very uncomfortable and yes, angry, with the inconsistencies you are getting from your surgeon's office.  I feel that the breast cancer patient should have every opportunity to make an informed decision and to feel as confident as you can be with the care you are receiving, and to me, that care also includes the degree to which the office staff takes care of the administrative stuff professionally and with as little disruption to you as possible.  After all, you are dealing with your diagnosis and all the emotional and physical ramifications of that.  It seems, from your description, that while you were told you were tentatively scheduled for tomorrow, that your surgeon won't be operating tomorrow.  If so, again, I encourage you to take the gift of extra time to seek a second opinion.  You may end up continuing with the same surgeon you have now, and that's fine, but you may also find you have some breathing room.  Oh, and keep breathing!!!  You will get through this.  ((hugs))
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2013 03:24PM summergal wrote: I want to say thanks to everyone and especially to mamasixtaz for your thoughtful and kind support.  Four days out and I can say that the soreness at the incision sites has diminished considerably.  But I still feel loopy and tired.  In reading a lot of your posts I've learned that the general anesthesia does a number on us and can linger for days (I didn't know that before now).  One thing I wasn't prepared for - my husband has been very supportive, with me up until surgery and there immediately after in post-op, but yesterday (two days post-surgery) I felt like he totally ignored me.  I know it's "not all about me" and over the past three months since DX I've really made efforts to keep BC from dominating every discussion, and I know this has been hard on him, too, and he might have just needed a day to process it all and needed to do that by himself, but that felt pretty lonesome yesterday.  I haven't cried in weeks, but I can feel it coming now.  I understand that everybody in a family deals with BC in different ways...I'm curious if those of you who see therapists feel it helps with the family issues?

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2013 01:50PM summergal wrote: Hi, everyone.  Two days out from my bilateral lumpectomies and SND on 9/12.  Still sore under my arms, but thankfully no axillary node dissection - the dye moved and they were able to take just the two sentinel nodes, one on each side.  Yesterday was rough - nauseated all day long and didn't do more than lay on the couch or in bed with ice chips and crackers.  Meds helped a little.  The worst part of surgery day for me was when I was having the needle locs, the radiologist used NO anesthetic, no numbing cream, no lidocaine, nothing!  So it was pretty intense getting the needles inserted; and I started to faint in the middle of the procedure.  Then coming out of the anesthesia was tough for me, nausea, sweating profusely and such sleepiness.  But everyone at the hospital was so nice and helpful, from the orderlies on up to the surgeons.  Taking it easy today; going to attempt a shower now.  Hope everyone post-surgery is resting comfortably and for those about to go into surgery in the next few days and weeks...all good wishes and blessings.
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2013 04:03AM summergal wrote: Hi, Lee1963 - welcome.  Sorry you have to be here, but I think you'll find this is a very caring community with lots of support to offer.  Regarding the wire (or "needle loc") - my tumors were very small, 9mm and 6mm, at least that's what they estimated based on my biopsies.  So, like Sandymomto3 suggested, I needed to have the wires inserted prior to my surgery so that the surgeons could take out the exact area, plus margins, of my cancerous tissue.  When I had my biopsies, the doctor inserted small clips (titanium metal) that stay in the breast not only to mark the areas of concern or tumor so that subsequent mammographies reveal that those areas have been looked at before, but also so that, in the event of surgery, and with my smaller tumors, the radiologist can essentially "hook" a wire to each clip so that he/she can find and remove the tumor.  I don't know if cancerous tissue looks different from non-cancerous tissue, but I'm assuming it looks pretty much the same, especially when the tumors are small.  As for the dye injection for the sentinel lymph node, my surgeon injected the dye after I was already under general anesthesia, so I was spared the pain of that.  And while I've heard that some patients have the dye or isotopes injected into the nipple/areola, mine was injected into plain old breast tissue.  My suggestion is to write down ALL of your questions and ask your surgeon each and every one before your surgery.  Even if it is hard to hear, I found it was much better knowing than wondering and being scared.  Good luck! I will be keeping you in thoughts and prayers for the 20th - hopefully we'll both have good news as that day I get the results of my path back!  (((HUGS)))
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2013 01:24PM summergal wrote: Sandra4611 - When I asked my BS if I should massage with cocoa butter or anything for the scars, he said, "Nope.  Soap and water and let it air dry."  That surprised me.  I think it would feel so much better if I could put some kind of lotion on them.  One other thing he said was to be very sure not to let that area get exposted to sunlight for at least a year, or the scars will really darken. I said, "Oh, dang!  Now I can't go to that nude beach we stumbled on last year!" ;)  And he said, "Just so you know, a t-shirt only has an SPF of 5."  Food for thought!

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2013 02:30AM summergal wrote: tressaliz - so glad you found this forum to share your feelings.  I know how you feel - the feelings flip-flopping back and forth. Mine flip-flop all the time about "did I pick the right surgical option?" (I'm also have lumpectomies).  I worry that in trying to preserve my breasts, and in listening to all the docs tell me that my cancer is non-aggressive, small, early stage, that I'm somehow "tricking" myself into being okay with lumpectomies, and worrying that I will wish I had gotten rid of all the tissue with mastectomies.  I hate having these choices.  Next week at this very time I will be immediately post-surgery, hopefully resting at home, and hopefully at peace with the decisions I have made.  Although I have a large and loving family and group of friends, I still feel very alone in the decision-making process around this.  And I'm also very worried that it's in my lymph nodes, too.  The ultimate worry is when they talk about survival rates.  That's when it really hits me.  I will say prayers for you that you can have some relief from all the worrying and stress, and of course that things go well on Monday.  Sending warmth your way!

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2013 04:02PM summergal wrote: Hi, ladies.  Just checking in...keeping vigil for those going through surgery today.  tuffenough - so glad to hear your LX went well and that you'll be able to help with the wedding!  What a special time. tessaliz and sandymomto3 - hope you're feeling better today after yesterday's surgeries.  Hope it's at least some relief to be starting on the treatment part of your journey. Feeling very nervous and nauseous as I wait to hear back from my surgeon today.  Realized yesterday when talking to one of his nurses that maybe I should have been scheduled for one more consultation, other than the second opinion, which was the one and only time I saw the surgeon, before surgery.  I had to remind the nurse (who knew nothing about me when she returned my call; they have several nurses in the office who return calls) that I'm having both breasts done...and when I said I was concerned that she didn't seem to know that, she got snippy and told me "don't get upset! I'm just returning a call to you. I don't know anything about it."  Well, that doesn't make me feel very confident!!  I felt very belittled at that point.  Now I'm less than 48 hours pre-surgery and still haven't talked with the doctor yet.  Anxious.

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2013 08:14PM summergal wrote: Hi, Nancy2013 - I wanted to post to you a few days ago, but was still so loopy from post-surgery.  It's so hard to know what caused BC for all of us.  It really could be anything.  I have a friend who did IVF and she's convinced that her BC is a result of that. I had my first child at 43 and was told by the surgeons that that could've contributed (i.e., uninterrupted estrogen for such a long time).  It didn't help when they said that, it just made me feel guilty and sad.  I have found that I'm not as interested in knowing how I got BC as I am in getting rid of it, but I certainly understand your questioning.  I hope you can find some peace around that as you wait for your surgery on the 25th.  Above all, please don't blame yourself (I don't mean to presume).  ((Hugs)).

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2013 05:35PM summergal wrote: Hi, lovely ones!  Hope you all can take at least one, peaceful, relaxed breath today and know that you are here and you are loved.  After going to the farmer's market and the grocery yesterday, I was surprised at how tired I became and suddenly realized that my dressings don't just hide topical incisions, but also some pretty major tissue excavation from last Thursday!  That's when my husband said, "Oh, yeah, the surgeon did say they had to 'go pretty hard at the one tumor all the way up against the chest wall.'" Now I know why my chest feels a little bit beaten up!  So, I am taking it easy today...and trying to keep the worrying wolf at bay regarding tomorrow's path report.  DawnCT - I agree with you about the wire!  I'm still wondering how often it is standard procedure to not be numbed at all for the wire loc.  I plan to ask my surgeon tomorrow.  As for my husband, he really is a great guy.  Mammasixtaz had mentioned that if my husband took a day away from tending to me and just did things for himself it would pay off, and it did - he washed, conditioned and combed the tangles out of my hair on Sunday.  I know he's worried, but he's very present with me and I'm grateful. Tuffenuff - Thank you so much for your kind words!  I'm glad if I've helped.  I never thought I'd know enough about breast cancer to be able to offer suggestions, but I do know that right after diagnosis is a very scary emotional place to be and that it's really important to have someone else "take you by the hand" and help you advocate for yourself.  Be good to yourself this weekend and give yourself something special - a spa treatment, a nice meal, a movie - whatever it is that makes you feel pampered.  You deserve it! Katlebbie - Thank you, too!  You have such a lovely, calming way of offering support - I wish you good luck and easy healing tomorrow! Hoping that antbigler, StacieRae and SchoolCounselor are all resting easy after surgery these past few days. What a big day that is now behind you - onto the rest of your life!   And keeping MBLizzy, Katlebbie and Lee1963 in thoughts, prayers and good wishes that you don't have too much worry today as you prepare for surgery coming up - keeping busy helped me and reaching out to let the friends and family around me know when my surgery day was coming up provided such comfort.  (((HUGS))) to all!

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2013 02:29PM summergal wrote: Hi, everyone.  So glad to have found this board.  I am scheduled for BLX with SNB on Sept. 12.   I'm 49, with a 6-year-old child, loving and supportive husband, and large family/group of friends.   Like many of you, I have struggled with my choice of surgery and now, facility, because I am having to act as intermediary between my cancer center, my insurance company and my oncologist/radiation therapist.   After two months of indecision, fear and worry, I just want to have the surgery, find out what else, if anything needs to be done surgically, and move on to treatment.  I can't say I'm one hundred percent comfortable with my surgical choice (I worry that by choosing BLX I'm giving up the opportunity to get all the current and future cancer out, and read on one of the other boards that someone had said they chose BMX because they had a "young child to live for."  I do, too, so I worry).  I'm sorry that each and every one of us is having to deal with all of these questions, worries and choices, but am encouraged by your presence here and knowing that if we all have to deal with this, we are at least able to support one another.
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2013 10:00PM summergal wrote: KKmattie2 - I had BRCA testing done and my insurance covered it because I met two of several criteria our cancer center uses to determine if insurance will cover - 1)I was diagnosed before age 50 and 2) while there is no other breast cancer in my family, I had male relatives who were diagnosed with other cancers.  Hopefully you'll fall under the same considerations (given your age and family history) so that your insurance will cover it.  Good luck with your surgery!
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2013 02:03PM summergal wrote: ((hugs)) back to you hobbesla4 - when I wake at night, and it's very often these days, I turn to the rosary, also, to help calm my fears and worries.  Hoping you'll be able to relax a bit this weekend, knowing that you are almost through one of the hardest segments of this journey.  Keeping you in prayers!
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2013 08:05PM summergal wrote: hobbesla4 - thank you for your kind words to all of us.  I had an MRI with contrast after my first stereotactic biopsy and had no problem with it.  The techs placed an IV port in my hand right before I walked to the MRI room and then they told me when they were going to inject the dye toward the end of the MRI.  The only thing they were really specific about was that I must not move AT ALL after they told me they were injecting the dye, because if I did, then they would have to pull me out and start all over again.  I kept my eyes closed during the whole thing (but I was laying face down so it wasn't too claustrophobic), and asked them to play music on the headphones so I had something to distract me from all the banging.  Peace and comfort from me to you. It will be okay.
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2013 07:13PM summergal wrote: Hi, everyone.  Received the best possible news at my follow-up appt today - no lymph node involvement and clear margins!  The right-side tumor was bigger than expected (that explains the soreness - ouch!).  Grateful...
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2013 04:22PM summergal wrote: SchoolCounselor - I'm so sorry to hear that you're in so much pain.  Isn't it ironic?  The way we stay healthy turns out to be a complication!  Good thing your PS is on top of it and prescribed the muscle relaxant.  Hope that helps.  Keep on the percocet (I am a week and a half out from my BLX and finally relented and resumed taking the percocet at nighttime because the incisions get so sting-y then).  Remember that you have been turned inside out so there are also incisions inside that are painful.  PLEASE be at peace with taking it easy and giving yourself the time you need to recover...If you take it slowly and easily for a couple of weeks, I think you'll heal faster and better.  It is hard to do, but remember, you have just been through an incredible battle.  Think about how you would want your precious daughters to heal if they were in your shoes - you wouldn't expect them to do too much too soon.  You may have to treat yourself as your own child!!  You deserve the R&R!!!  Gentle, gentle hugs to you.

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2013 08:20PM summergal wrote: CJC... you mentioned that "hardly any of us with our same diagnoses have had chemo; just hormonal therapy."  Just want to weigh in and say it is possible that someone with a BMX might have to have radiation, in addition to chemo and hormonal therapy.  Remember that ongoing treatment is not really about the diagnosis, but about what they find in the surgery. Sometimes the tumors are up against the chest wall and even with a BMX, the BS or RO will recommend radiation therapy to "get" the cancerous cells that may still be lurking there.  My BS said that if I had had even one positive node, I would be doing chemo.  And even though I had all three of my nodes were negative, my MO just ordered the oncotype DX test to determine the likelihood of a recurrence and therefore, the possibility that I'd need to do chemo before I even start radiation.  So, I think it's a mixed bag.  Everyone is different, everyone's cancer is different, too and perhaps unfortunately, everyone's doctor is different (i.e., there isn't one solid protocol for every patient who presents with whatever diagnosis).  I, too, prepared myself for the worst.  It's good to consider all the possibilities.  I know you're scared.  In the days before my surgery I was constantly questioning myself and my decisions, and I hate to say it, but I still do question them.  We do the best with the information we have at the time.  Will keep you in prayers that you can have some peaceful moments before Thursday.  ((hugs)).
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2013 05:23PM summergal wrote: julieped - yes, I am still taking percocet at night so that the pain doesn't wake me and keep me up.  I fully believe that pain meds are there for a reason - to relax and comfort your body so that the parts you are "holding" (aka stiffening, hunching, contracting, whatever) can be released and the healing can continue.  If your doc prescribed enough pain meds for you to be taking, I say take them. You've already been through hell, you don't have to put yourself through high water, too.
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2013 01:29PM summergal wrote: Hi, all. Tomorrow I have my first MO appt and get the results of my oncotype dx test. What should I expect at this appointment? I've heard others on these boards say that I should expect some kind of examination, blood pressure, temp, etc. Is that standard and if this doesn't happen, should I request it? What kinds of questions should I ask? I have seen some people say that their MO prescribed tamoxifen at the outset of their radiation. Others said their MOs want them to wait until they're finished with radiation before taking the tamoxifen. What is the risk? If I find out I don't need chemo at tomorrow's appt, I expect to begin radiation on both breasts in November. Thank you for your suggestions
